awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: IUSE-HER: Cultivating Inclusive Identities of Engineers and Computer Scientists: Expanding Efforts to Infuse Inclusive Excellence in Undergraduate Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop inclusive professional identities among engineering and computer science students through the process of redesigning undergraduate curricula. Inclusive professional identities are defined here as engineering and computer science students with: (a) the necessary technical knowledge, skills, and abilities to work in their chosen field, (b) an appreciation for how all kinds of diversity strengthen engineering and computer science as disciplines, and (c) knowledge of how to act in inclusive ways and create inclusive environments within their field. This project builds on a prior exploratory IUSE grant to develop, implement, and assess curricula for first-year engineering courses designed to help beginning engineering students identify with an inclusive vision of the engineering profession. The first objective is to transfer the first-year curricula to three other universities with different institutional characteristics and extend this curricula from engineering into computer science. Throughout this process, the pathways and barriers to successful transfer and adoption of this curricula will be studied. The second objective is to expand efforts into the second and third year courses in engineering and computer science in ways that sustain student engagement with diversity and inclusion. The project will develop and assess (a) discipline- and course-specific diversity activities (in particular, case studies from the engineering and computer science profession), and (b) training for graduate teaching assistants and faculty to facilitate effective and inclusive teams. The third objective is to measure both the short term and long term impact of the diversity and inclusion activities on the development of inclusive professional identities in students. 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its transformative approach toward changing engineering and computer science collegiate cultures. This work complements initiatives that support historically underrepresented populations: rather than focusing exclusively on members of underrepresented groups, the focus is on preparing all students to work in diverse environments and to leverage inclusive behaviors that will support retention of students in STEM from all backgrounds, underrepresented and majority alike. The broader impact of this project allows for development and distribution of curricula that will prepare all STEM students to enact inclusive professional behaviors. Creating inclusive climates in collegiate STEM departments contributes to broadening participation by ensuring that students from underrepresented groups experience equitable learning environments where they can participate fully in STEM learning. STEM professionals who are prepared to infuse diverse perspectives in their everyday practices and create inclusive work environments carry great potential to make robust contributions for the public good of society.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project brought together educators and researchers from Colorado State University, West Virginia University, University of Denver, and Metropolitan State University of Denver. The primary objective was to develop curriculum and activities that support the cultivation of inclusive professional identities in engineering and computer science students. The research team defined inclusive professional identities by emphasizing four key components: 1) competence in applying disciplinary knowledge, skills, and abilities, 2) appreciation of how diversity strengthens a discipline, 3) an ability to act inclusively and create inclusive environments, and 4) consideration of a professional endeavor’s impact on diverse populations.  The overall multi-institutional project produced numerous publications.

 

The initial grant year at the University of Denver (DU) focused exclusively on engineering. Activities in the first year included a welcome presentation from college leadership to establish an inclusive norm, an interactive theater performance that addressed intra-group gender bias and conflict, and a survey for both assessment and pedagogical purposes. The subsequent two project years extended the scope to include both engineering and computer science, while the fourth year concentrated solely on computer science.

 

In additional to overall project research contributions, At DU, several curriculum innovations were introduced, studied, and published during the grant period:

 

1.     (Engineering)  Inclusive First Year Engineering Design Module. A module was developed and integrated into our first-year engineering design course, centered around a hairdryer design activity. This activity, exploring thermodynamics and the importance of diversity in design and teamwork, prompted students to consider the technical and user aspects of design. Survey data and reflections indicated that students gained an understanding of the benefits of diverse team compositions and the importance of addressing user needs in the design process.  A paper describing this intervention was published is ASEE 2023.

 

2.     (Engineering and Computer Science) Living and Learning Community on Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (JEDI) Technology Ethics.  In 2021-22, we piloted a living and learning community focused on JEDI technology Ethics. This model included shared dorm living, a two-credit course, and co-curricular activities. The course covered topics such as racism, sexism, social media, AI, robotics, privacy, biomedical engineering, and diversity in engineering and computer science education.   A paper describing this intervention was published is ASEE 2022.

 

3.     (Computer Science) Interactive Theater Class/Lecture for First-Year Computer Science Majors. For three years, an interactive theater class/lecture was offered to all first-year computer science majors. Professional theater scenarios addressing gender bias issues engaged students in critical thinking. The scenarios, followed by discussions and student participation as protagonists, proved successful in raising awareness about bias issues in computer science. A paper describing this intervention was published in ITiCSE 2022.

 

4.     (Computer Science) DEI Component in a Technical Text Mining Course.  In 2021, a DEI component was added to a technical text mining course. Students applied naive Bayes classification to a DEI survey result dataset, distinguishing between "technical" and "equity" responses. End of term survey results indicated the course positively influenced students' views on the importance of DEI. A paper describing this intervention was published in SIGCSE 2021.

 

5.     (Computer Science) First-Year Computing Science Lecture Demonstrating Computational Codification of Racial Oppression. Starting in 2020, a first-year computing science lecture demonstrated how computing can perpetuate systemic racial oppression. Students designed a loan decision algorithm, unknowingly creating an algorithm that perpetuated financial redlining. Subsequent discussions and additional lectures explored the societal impact of computing products, emphasizing the importance of ethical considerations. End-of-term survey results indicated students found both lectures important and personally valuable.  A paper describing this intervention has been submitted for publication.

 

Beyond the direct impact on students and the engineering/CS education research community, this NSF-funded project influenced policy changes within the Ritchie School of Engineering and Computer Science at DU. Changes included a required DEI-focused section in annual faculty reviews, faculty development opportunities, and the required use of a DEI rubric in faculty hiring committees.

 

Overall, the project significantly contributed to the literature on integrating diversity, equity, and inclusion lessons into technical courses, providing valuable insights into student and faculty attitudes toward such content. 

 

We note that Large Language Models were used to improve the clarity of this report
